article:
As a physician who travels quite a lot, I spend a lot of time on planes listening for that dreaded "Is there a doctor on board?" announcement. I've been   _  only once -- for a
woman who had merely fainted. But the  _  made me
quite curious about how  _  this kind of thing
happens. I wondered what I would do if  _  with a
real midair medical emergency -- without access  _  a
hospital staff and the usual emergency equipment. So  _  theNew England Journal of Medicinelast week  _  a
study about in-flight medical events, I read it  _  interest.
  The study estimated that there are a(n)   _  of 30 in-flight medical emergencies on U.S. flights every day. Most of them are not  _  ; fainting and dizziness are the most frequent complaints.  _  13% of them -- roughly four a day -- are serious enough to  _  a pilot to change course.   Let's face it: plane rides are   _  . For starters, cabin pressures
